Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project will support student to attend the IEEE International Symposium on Workload Characterization (IISWC) to be held in Austin, TX, Nov 6-8, 2011. IISWC is a long running and well recognized workshop dedicated to the crucial topic of workload characterization, and this funding provides students to be exposed to this important workshop on workload modeling and characterization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IEEE International Symposium on Workload Characterization (IISWC) is the premier international forum for the presentation of research results in characterization of computing system workloads. IISWC started out as Workshop on Workload Characterization (WWC) in 1998 and became a symposium in 2005. The symposium is sponsored by the IEEE Computer Society and the Technical Committee on Computer Architecture. NSF awarded a travel grant of $5000 for supporting student travel to IISWC 2011 held during November 6-8, 2011 in Austin, TX.

 

The travel grant was announced on the IISWC web site as soon as the NSF approval was received.  Emails were sent to the IISWC mailing lists. We sent emails to prior attendees and other faculty from different Universities. During the conference, further announcements were made that travel grants are available. Student attendees were encouraged to apply.

 

Fourteen applications were received from Universities within US. All applicants were tentatively promised partial support. Twelve of the applicants attended the conference, and we gave awards to all 12 of them.  Two applicants from the local University were awarded $100 each. The applicants from nearby cities (Houston and San Antonio) were given $400 each. Other applicants were given $500 each. The decisions were made jointly by John Carter and Lizy John.

The 12 awardees could be classified as follows further illustrating the utility of the awards:

 

Presenting/non presenting: 9 presenting, 3 non-presenting

Author/non-author:  8 regular paper authors, 1 poster author, 3 non-author

Male/female: 9 male, 3 female

Minority: 1 Hispanic, multiple Asian

Each student submitted a 2-page summary of how they benefitted from attending the symposium.

All travel receipts were sent to the University of Texas. The University of Texas reimbursed the expenses up to the allocated amount according to the submitted receipts.


Last Modified: 11/13/2012
Modified by: Lizy K John
